title: Ardglass to host meeting on future of lighthouse beam
story: A PUBLIC meeting in Ardglass tonight will hear about revised plans for the future of the iconic sweeping beam at St Johnrsquos Point lighthouse in Killough.Senior officials from the Commissioner of Irish Lightsare hosting the meeting at the villagersquos Golf Club at pm.CIL officials say they have tested and developed new technology to retain the historic lens and sweeping beam ldquoto ensure the environmental footprint and safety standards at the site are improved.But the proposal has not secured the support of the Lecale Lightkeepers, the campaign group who claim CILrsquos plan will reduce the range of the beam by up to nine miles.Campaigners say that their drive to preserve the beam includes the historic Fresnel lens rotation mechanism ldquowhich continues to work wonderfully well over a century after it was installed.CIL said that since plans for the future of the lighthouse were first discussed with the local community in March , ldquosignicant research and development has taken place to facilitate finding a suitable solution to the goal of retaining the historical First Order Fresnel rotating lens, while ensuring the environmental footprint and safety standards at the site are improved.The Commissioner says that with ldquosignicant progress now made in this regard, engineering works at the Killough site mdash planned for  mdash include the retention of the rotating lens, the necessary removal of ldquohighly toxic mercury from the site and the discontinuation of an inefficient diesel generator which ldquois best practice and standard across all Irish Lightsrsquo sites.CIL insists that it wants to safeguard the historic Killough site and has now developed and tested new technology to achieve a ldquosustainable solution that will enable retention of the historic lens and sweeping beam at St. Johnrsquos Point.Campaigners say that while they accept there is some concession on CILrsquos part in proposing to keep the sweeping beam at the lighthouse, they have been informed by the Commissioner that its range will be reduced.They also claim that the beamrsquos iconic ldquoloom will be lost, robbing the lighthouse of what they describe as its ldquointangible heritage.The Lecale Lightkeepers say Newry Mourne and Down Council has already voted unanimously to protect the sweeping beamrsquos current mechanism and trustrsquos that CIL will not be given planning permission to proceed with its proposal.ldquoThe lighthouse is a listed building and its character, the light, must be protected, declared the campaignersrsquo spokesperson.ldquoWith the loss of the historic lights at Fastnet, Mew and Tory it is even more vital that St Johnrsquos Point should be kept for heritage purposes. Moreover, it is a beautul feature of our nocturnal landscape, much loved by the local communities.The Lecale Lightkeepers have also confirmed this week they have been invited to make a presentation to Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee on October  in Newry..prettyPhoto

title: Aughlisnafin take place in JFC final
story: AUGHLISNAFIN booked their place in a historic first ever county championship final since their reformation in  at Clonduff on Friday night.Three times on the wrong end of a semi-final result, this was one they will surely savour.The lsquoFin led by four point at half-time and despite only two points between the teams in the end, they could have had another three goals.The lsquoFin started the game on the front foot and nearly had the ball in the Dundrum net inside the first minute when Adam Garland palmed the ball inches over the crossbar, but it was an important opening score, nonetheless.Experienced campaigner Paul Flanagan curled over a minute later to double the lsquoFinrsquos advantage. In the fth minute a free was given away by the lsquoFin defence and Cormac Venney slotted over from the m line.In the sixth minute a superb full-pitch move from the lsquoFin was finished by Breannain McComiskey, restoring the two-point lead.A minute later Garland was clinical when he drove to the net to put the lsquoFin firmly in the driving seat. Shea Croskery raced through moments later and drove for goal, but saw his effort go wide and Dundrumrsquos relief was palpable.Instead of going eight points behind, Dundrum did well to re-group and points from Aidan Fegan and a second Venney free cut the deficit back to three points.Oran Flanagan sent over the next three points in the second quarter of the game with Glavin doing the same for Dundrum. Garland and Croskery also raised the white flag with their strikes to leave the lsquoFin with a half-time lead of - to -.Fegan got the first point of the second half for Dundrum with three minutes gone and a third free kick of the game was landed by Venney by the end of the third quarter.While the lsquoFin had not yet scored, it wasnrsquot for the want of trying as a few opportunities were missed and Dundrum lsquokeeper Eamon King pulled off a superb double save, the first from Croskery and the follow up from Chris Doran.Oran Flanagan was having a good game and he sent over his fourth point of the match and a superb effort from Shane McCann restored the lsquoFinrsquos four point half-time advantage with ten minutes remaining.Dundrum continued to threaten, but other than two more excellent points from their standout player Kyle Glavin, the lsquoFin defence held strong and kept the dangerous duo of Venney and Fegan scoreless the remainder of the game.Dundrum half forward Fegan was sent to the line after getting a second yellow in the final throes of the game. Excellent game management from the lsquoFin as they saw out a first ever championship win over their derby rivals.Impressive performances from Garland and Flanagan in attack while in defence the full back line of Brannigan, Dillon and Willoughby was superb with McComiskey putting in a big sht on the .Dundrum were best served by Eamon King in goal, Hurley, McShane in defence and their key forward Glavin.Dundrum: E King, R Carey, R McGuigan, C Miskelly, T McShane, J Hurley, A Doyle, N Rogers, Odhran McKibbin, P Curry, A Fegan , K Glavin , Oisisn McKibbin, C Venney , C Mulholland. Subs: M Coughlan, D McComiskey.Aughlisnafin: C Croskery, J Brannigan, T Dillon, S Willoughby, O OrsquoToole, S Fitzsimmons, S McCann , D Steele, O Flanagan , S Croskery , C Doran, B McComiskey , P Flanagan , A Garland , M Stratton. Subs: R Quinn, S Mooney, R Murphy, B Ogle, C Dillon, R Feenan, J McCawley, B Willoughby..prettyPhoto

title: Ballykinler Cadets get ready for fun times
story: BALLYKINLER Army Cadets began a new school term armed with a fortnight of fun-filled memories gained at their annual camp in Liverpool over the summer.Every cadet took part in a packed programme of sport, adventure and outdoor pursuits which helped them build confidence, resilience and make new friendships.Colonel Sam McCammond, Commandant of nd Battalion Army Cadet Force NI, said parents know how dficult it can be to prise teenagers away from social media and into the fresh air, explaining that the young people ldquoshowed a real appetite for the great outdoors.He continued: ldquoThe Ballykinler Cadets were up for every challenge we threw at them, bringing incredible energy and enthusiasm and good humour to all kinds of new sports and outdoor pursuits.ldquoThey may be out of school, but at the annual camp they were learning something new every day as well as making lasting and supportive friendships.ldquoProviding those opportunities, complete with expert tuition and supportive, professional supervision would usually stretch most family budgets, but thankfully the camp is affordable fun for all, he said.ldquoAs a matter of policy, we aim to ensure all our activities are either low cost or totally free. We even provide free unorms.Ballykinler Cadets meet every Wednesday at the cadet training centre at pm. Potential new members are welcome to come along to see cadet le for themselves.To find out more about cadet membership or to arrange a visit log on to www.reservesandcadetsni.org.uk.prettyPhoto

title: Belfast Gospel Choir set for music concert
story: A HOST of top raffle prizes, including a pound travel voucher, are up for grabs in next weekendrsquos fundraising concert in Downpatrick featuring the Belfast Community Gospel Choir.The September  event mdash in aid of Cancer Focus NI mdash is being organised by sisters Emma and Evie Telford in memory of their mum Lorna.The Quoile Bar and Bistro at the Strangford Road is the venue for the concert which is being sponsored by Phoenix Natural Gas.Next Saturdayrsquos event takes place just days after the fth anniversary of Mrs Telfordrsquos passing following a long battle with lung cancer, despite being a non-smoker.Emma and Evie have organised several events in aid of Cancer Focus, raising thousands pounds for the organisation as their way of giving something back to the charity which provided key support to them at a particularly challenging time in their lives.All proceeds from the forthcoming concert go directly to a charity which has worked with many families across the district.Emma and Evie have also produced a fundraising concert programme which has been generously supported by a number of local businesses, with the sisters particularly grateful for the generosity they have been shown.In addition to the pound holiday voucher, kindly sponsored by Downe Travel, the other prizes include a pound voucher for The Cuan Restaurant in Strangford, pound voucher for the Millbrook Lodge Hotel in Ballynahinch, afternoon tea at Newcastlersquos Burrendale Hotel and the Old Post Office in Lisbane, luncheon voucher for the Smugglerrsquos Table in Killyleagh and a day family pass to the stunning Montalto Estate in Ballynahinch.Other prizes include vouchers for McBridersquos Fashions of the Temple and Ritarsquos Fashions in Downpatrick, meat vouchersfor IK Meats and McGreevyrsquos butchers, also Downpatrick and pound voucher for Picnic in Killyleagh.Tickets for a Belfast Giants ice hockey match, W family pass, pound voucher for the Beau Visage beauty salon in Downpatrick and a facial and massage at the No  Day Spa in the town are also up for grabs, alongside two tickets for the Omniplex Cinema in Downpatrick.Tickets priced pound. for the September  concert featuring the Belfast Community Gospel Choir which starts at .pm are available at Down Recorder reception or from Davidor Emma Telford .A limited number of tickets will be available to purchase on the night as will a number of childrenrsquos tickets priced pound. Tickets are also available on line via the Cancer Focus website or contact charity representative Barbara Long, telephone , email barbaralong@cancerfocusni.org.On the night of the concert, parking will be available at Down Hockey Clubrsquos Malone Park ground which is opposite the entrance to the Quoile Bar and Bistro..prettyPhoto

title: Bold Bethany strikes gold yet again in London
story: SEAFORDE golden girl Bethany Firth completed a four-medal haul at the last weekrsquos World Para-swimming Championships.The  year-old finished the London meet with a silver medal in the m on Saturday to add to m backstroke and mixed freestyle relay gold medals plus a m freestyle silver.Firth was badly hindered by a shoulder injury in Saturdayrsquos final as she finished four seconds behind her Russian rival Valeriia Shabalina.Despite winning four Paralympic gold medals during her career, Firth went into these championships having never clinched a world title.She won three silver medals at the  world championships in Montreal, but after missing the  championships through injury, was unable to compete at the  championships in Mexico after the British team pulled out following an earthquake in the country.Firth, who recovered from a long-term shoulder injury to represent Great Britain at the London Aquatics Centre, battled through ing pain to touch the wall in .:. to win silver.ldquoMy injury started to come back after this morning so I was so happy to even be in the final, let alone come away with a silver medal, said Firth.ldquoIrsquom so happy with that swim. I couldnrsquot ask for more. I was really happy with my heat time so going past that in the final made me really happy.ldquoItrsquos been a great week not only for me, but for Great Britain as a whole, added Firth.ldquoWersquove had so many younger swimmers here and Irsquom really hoping they have been inspired to continue succeeding by this event. Irsquove really enjoyed my experience here and Irsquom looking forward to building ahead of Tokyo ..prettyPhoto

title: Call for pitch upgrade at Dunleath Park
story: THE Downpatrick Youth League has made an impassioned plea for an urgent upgrade of pitches at Dunleath Park.The league says it has been operating with sub-standard facilities for over  years and is calling for immediate action.The league currently has the use of five pitches at Dunleath Park, which are used for games at U-, U-, U- and development levels.The slightest sign of rain iniably means that all but two of the pitches become unplayable and heavier showers shut the park completely.In addition to flooding, there is also the additional problem of raw sewage bubbling to the surface in places.In recent years, the league has been forced to play games in Newcastle, Castlewellan, Drumaness, Crossgar Strangford, Killough and Ardglass.League officials say an obvious solution would be to convert the currently unused all-weather shale pitch into a G facility.League secretary Kevin Torney said: ldquoWe believe that the pitch should be upgraded to a G facility with floodlights and a perimeter fence. The upgrading of the pitch is certainly sustainable financially, given the amount of usage it would get.ldquoWe have lost  teams to other leagues in the past few years and they have all cited poor facilities as their main reason for moving to play in the the Lisburn or South Belfast Leagues, he added.Mr Torney said it was essential that proper facilities were put in place to enable the league to avoid weekly postponements of games.ldquoWe are left every year with a fixture congestion because of postponements and in order to arrest the haemorrhaging of clubs from the league we must address this issue immediately.The league are being supported by South Down MP Chris Hazzard, who has called on Newry, Mourne and Down Council to ldquofinally deliver fit for purpose pitches for the local community in Downpatrick.He continued: ldquoThe current provision of sports pitches at Dunleath Park is nothing short of a disgrace.ldquoDunleath Park is used extensively by the Downpatrick Youth Football League with hundreds of young footballers playing each weekend, but yet againthis week, parts of the pitches have been closed to the public as raw sewage has come to the surface.ldquoIt is an absolute shame that in the shadow of our fantastic new leisure centre here in Downpatrick our local young people are expected to make do with substandard pitches that not only flood for most of the winter months, but are regularly polluted with raw sewage.Mr Hazzard believes that Downpatrick deserves much better treatment.ldquoAs the county town, Downpatrick deserves to have the very best in local sports provision, and that simply isnrsquot the case at the moment.ldquoIt is deeply disappointing that so many of our young footballers are left to travel to Lisburn and Belfast each weekend to play football. That must not be allowed to continue.Mr Hazzard added: ldquoWhilst there is no getting away from the fact that Dunleath Park is in a flood plain area, I would have sympathy with local sports clubs that feel that this is too easily put up as a hurdle to any investment, and that the council should actively consider a range of solutions in order to deliver suitable facilities.ldquoI want to thank those local sports clubs and Downpatrick Youth League representatives who continue to work tirelessly in order to provide local sporting opportunities for our young people and I will now be making representation to senior council management in order to make all their voices heard..prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan forest cycle in the park family event in aid of Knockevin Special School
story: ALL roads lead to Castlewellan Forest Park this Sunday for a special event to raise money for Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick and celebrate the benefits of cycling for everyone.The lsquocycle in the parkrsquo event is being organised by the schoolrsquos Parent Staff Association to raise funds to help purchase new bikes for pupils to help them experience nature and the great outdoors.Sundayrsquos all ability event mdash which runs from am until pm ndash is being billed as a celebration of cycling and will have something for families and special needs adventurers, hard core mountain bikers, club riders, children and young people.The event is being hosted by the Kilmegan Velo Cycling Club with its chairman, Sean Warnock, inviting all cyclists to make their way to the forest park for the event.He said: ldquoThe aim is to get families and friends to experience cycling in a safe setting but full of adventure and we have events for all abilities.ldquoThere will be family trail quests, agility skills for kids, a full time-trial on the red trails, special needs bikes and a Sunday club fuel stop. We have something for everyone and McConveys Cycles in Belfast have given us a professional bike mechanic for the day so you can get a once over and some advice for free.Knockevin parent, Tara Haughian mdash who is also helping organise the event mdash said she has been ldquostunned by the reaction and the generosity the event has inspired.ldquoWe have had the most amazing offers, donations, and assistance from all corners, she revealed. ldquoVouchers, cash prizes, food, volunteers, it really is inspiring to see how much people want to help make it a success.ldquoIrsquom a parent of Ted, a child at Knockevin and the chance for him to take part in an event like this alongside other children means a lot. Irsquom especially looking forward to the family trail quest the chance to get your family or a mix of friends to head off and experience the beauty of this natural setting is fantastic.ldquoTara, who is part of the Downpatrick schoolrsquos Parent Staff Association, said everyone is grateful to Kilmegan VC for fundraising for Knockevin.ldquoWe are amazed at the generosity of all our sponsors, donators, volunteers. We have tried to keep a complete list on our Facebook page, but it keeps growing, she revealed.ldquoItrsquos great that children, young people and adults with physical or learning disabilities visiting the forest park can have the opportunity to attend an event like this and get the chance to try out an adapted bike.ldquoWe are very grateful to Newry, Mourne and Down Council for letting Kilmegan Velo Club to use the adapted bikes. We have a few trikes and hand bikes in Knockevin, but itrsquos not enough and their upkeep can also be challenging.Looking ahead to Sunday Tara added: ldquoSome people may want only a short discovery session on one of the adapted bikes and we are very grateful to the Forest Service for the use of a quieter smoother surface area to let people have a gentle introduction to cycling. For others feeling a bit more confident, a lakeside cycle might appeal with volunteers on hand to help.Velo Club member, Michael Donnelly, is encouraging those into their mountain biking to put their name down for the Red Trail time trial. He said Kilmegan VC volunteers will clock the riders with a pound McConvey Cycles voucher up for grabs.Michael said the Kilmegan Clubrsquos junior section is running an agility course sohills and thrills arenrsquot necessarily for peoplersquos cup of tea, they might want to practice a few skills and warm up on the agility course ahead of the agility obstacle course. Sundayrsquos event has also secured the back of Disability Sport NI is delighted this event is happening.Organisers have laid on a range of refreshments with donations with Shimna College parents helping with these on the day, with healthy fruit snacks provided by The Fresh Food Centre, in Castlewellan and Hales Fruit and Veg in Newcastle.For more information about the event email kilmeganvc@gmail.prettyPhoto

title: Council’s £12m outlay to spend a penny
story: PUBLIC toilets throughout Newry, Mourne and Down Council area are to feature in a pound.m upgrade.The news has been welcomed by Slieve Croob councillors Roisin Howell, Cathy Mason and Alan Lewis with the investment part of a major review of current and future provision.Cllr Mason said that as there was only one public convenience facility in Castlewellan, the news was particularly welcome.ldquoAs we are all aware, the district is crying out for more and better quality toilet facilities, she said.ldquoWithin my own area I know there is a need for improved toilet facilities, for example in Drumaness where we have two fantastic play parks which are used by not only local children but also neighbouring communities. At the minute they have use of the facilities within the Dan Rice Hall, however, this is dictated by its opening hours.ldquoWhilst myself and Cllr Howell welcome this news, we would urge the council to ensure it as provision within its strategy for the prevention of vandalism, which is a scourge in all of our communities.Cllr Howell urged the council to pay special attention to the Dundrum area which does not a public convenience as yet.This is something that I have been lobbying for during my time in council, she said.ldquoDundrum is a bustling tourist village which attracts many visitors and is therefore crying out for this facility. Numerous residents and business owners in Dundrum and surrounding areas have contacted me regarding this issue.Cllr Howell added: ldquoFor too long, Dundrum has been overlooked. I really hope the council will take note of this when undertaking these upgrades. I would hope that a facility like this would cater for the needs of all sectors of the community and the council will take into consideration the requirements of those with disabilities.Cllr Lewis said toilets for Dundrum needed to be a priority for the council.He said: ldquoDundrum is punching well above its weight in terms of tourism so we as a council must ensure that we are encouraging and aiding tourism by ensuring that basic amenities are available.ldquoI have asked council officials to make contact with other departments and agencies to investigate the possibility of land being leased or purchased within Dundrum village, andland is identied then Dundrum must be a spending priority, the village has waited long enough.ldquoI would be extremely disappointedDundrum did not benefit from this tremendous investment in public conveniences across our district..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C September 18%2C 1979
story: KILLOUGH mdash Down council officials are racing against the clock to bring Killough harbour into public ownership before the end of the year.If they fail to beat the December  deadline they could lose Government sanction to carry out a restoration scheme to establish the harbour as a yachting centre.Solicitors have already been briefed to draw up papers to vest a large chunk of harbour property mdashbut vesting procedure can take, on average, six months to complete, and Killough is not going to be an easy one.The Department of Commerce is offering  per cent grand-aid to local authorities to improve small harbours mdash provided they are in public ownership and schemes agreed by the end of the year.The problem at Killough is that nobody knows who owns the ious bits and pieces of land around the harbour and even after a six-year search there are still disputes and legal wrangles surrounding title deeds.Most of the land formerly belonged to the Bangor Estate but a number of people have claimed to have bought portions from the Estate years ago. Title deeds, usually the easiest of documents to trace, have become impossible to track down.Three people are laying claim to the pier alone and a legal row is pending about whether a contract was broken over the sale of pier some time ago.Against this backcloth, Down council official have been trying to bring the harbour into public ownership since the publication of the Governmentrsquos cash-help promise in July . Before then they had already spent four years attempting to trace owners.This week councillors decided to end their six-year search and apply for vesting mdash a statutory power which enables a Government department to buy land compulsorily, despite the wishes of the owner.But they were warned by council administrative officer, Mr Owen OrsquoConnor, that it would be a dficult vesting order and he could not guarantee that the whole of the inner bay of Killough would be acquired before December.The last-ditch attempt to beat the deadline was sparked off by Downpatrick councillor, Mr John Ritchie, who has been trying to push the council into buying the harbour since . On Monday he was clearly angry that time was running out.POLITICS mdash A suggestion that South Down MP, Enoch Powell, should accompany a Down council deputation to Stormont was kicked out by SDLP councillors this week.The suggestion was surprisingly made by industry minister, Mr Giles Shaw, who has agreed to meet a council deputation to discuss industrial affairs in Down district.In a letter to councillors, Mr Shaw suggested that Mr Powell should be advised of the meeting and,convenient, should accompany the council delegation.SDLP councillor, Mr Eddie McGrady, described the ministerrsquos decision as ldquoodd and said he had never come across anything like it before in his  years in government affairs.He thought the minister was ldquousurping the councilrsquos decision to form its own deputation and he believed the motive behind the suggestion was not altogether altruistic.He told councillors: ldquoWhat is happening is that a new precedent is being proposed to us. A corporate body has almost been directed to include a political representative on its deputation. This will create tensions which this council and district can do without.Mr Sean Quinnthought it was ldquorather arrogant of the minister to make the suggestion and he believed that Mr Powell was like previous South Down MPs, who, he said, had not satisfactorily served the constituency.Official Unionist councillor, Mrs Ethel Smyth, said she would resent it as much as anybodyshe felt the councilrsquos powers were being usurped, but on this occasion she thought it was only natural that Mr Powell should join the deputation.She told councillors: ldquoMr Powell has worked consistently very hard for all sections of the community and nobody could accuse him of working for one party or another. He is one of the best constituency MPs at Westminster.A motion by Mrs Smyth to invite Mr Powell on the deputation was defeated by nine votes to seven mdash a defeat which did not go down well with Official Unionist, Mr William Finlay, who told the SDLP members: ldquoThat was just a political vote. You are not worried whether people in the district get a job or not.BALLYNAHINCH mdash The streets of Ballynahinch will have Christmas lighting this year mdash at leastthe townrsquos Chamber of Commerce have their way.At a well attended meeting of the Chamber on Tuesday evening, it was unanimously agreed to purchase the lights in an effort to brighten the townrsquos main thoroughfare for the festive season.Whether they are erected and illuminated, stress the Chamber, now depends entirely on the business community and townspeople of Ballynahinch.This step forward was made possible by support from a number of traders in the town and the exhaustion of the chamberrsquos present funds.The Ballynahinch committee feel that what other towns in the locality have achieved they can emulated.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Councillor Mr Eamon OrsquoNeill said this week he is still hopeful that some industry can be attracted to the vacant factories at Castlewellan and Annsborough.Mr OrsquoNeill, who has been fighting for Government intervention since the factories closed last month, revealed that efforts have been made to attract new industries.He told a meeting of Down councillors that although nothing had yet happened, he believed that the efforts to attract new industries had been lsquoconscientiousrsquo.ldquoIt is a lamentable situation with two factories lying idle but I still remain hopeful that something will come out of it, said Mr OrsquoNeill.MOURNES mdash A planned motor cycle competition on the slopes of Slieve Donard in Newcastle has been turned down by local councillors.Councillors agreed on Monday that the event would encourage the improper use of the Mourne Mountains because it was planned in an area of outstanding natural beauty.ldquoEvents such as this should be discouraged to preserve the amenities of the area, said a council spokesman.The event, called lsquoEndeavour Motor Cyclersquo, was to have been staged by the Mourne Motor Cycle Club.DOWNPATRICK mdash Army bomb experts carried out a controlled explosion on an explosive device which had been placed on a windowsill of the Northern Bank at the junction of St Patrickrsquos Avenue and Market Street, Downpatrick, on Thursday evening.Police received a call at .pm stating that there was a suspect device at the premises and the bomb experts were called in. Some structural damage was caused to the building.Detectives at Downpatrick are anxious to talk to any person who may have seen the device being placed or who can give any information.CROSSGAR mdash A  year-old Bangor man jumped to his death from an ambulance transferring him from the Ulster Hospital, Dundonald to Downpatrick on Saturday morning.He was James Johnston, of Abbottrsquos Close, Bangor, and he jumped from the ambulance as it passed through Crossgar, hitting his head on the ground.He was taken to the Royal Victoria Hospital, Belfast, where he died about seven hours later.COMBER mdash Sometime during last weekend vandals entered the grounds of Andrews Memorial Primary School, Comber, and daubed a rear wall of the school with a carpet adhesive substance..prettyPhoto

title: Groups to access recycling areas in bid to reuse items
story: INNOVATIVE plans have been unveiled to allow groups and charities across the district to reuse ious items dumped at household recycling centres in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch.To date,  groups have expressed an interest in using items left by the public at the three local centres including bicycles, furniture, paint, building materials and household bric-a-brac.Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash which is spearheading the initiative across all its household recycling centres mdash plans to launch a pilot project next month which will run until the end of March.Items which groups and charities including the Inverbrena Community Association, Newcastle Community Cinema, Downpatrick-based charity Le Change, Changes Lives, Castlewellan Regeneration and MYMY in Newcastle express an interest in will be housed in special containers at each of the three sites.The local authority has agreed a formal reuse system with the pilot scheme monitored monthly to test how successful it is.Confirmation of the recycling scheme was outlined at a recent meeting of the local authorityrsquos Regulatory and Technical Services Committee and secured the support of local politicians who are keen to help local charities and groups.While a wide iety of items are to be reused, electrical goods left at recycling centres are not included in the new scheme as they are currently separated for collection and separate recycling.Moving forward, council officials plan to work with representatives from local groups and charities to understand their particular needs and the items they are keen to secure for their respective organisations.It has also been confirmed that a rota will be established to ensure that collection dates can be arranged for the groups and charities which sign up to the scheme.Over the coming weeks, council officials will liaise with the ious groups to agree collection days and advertise the scheme. Contact will also be made with the Environment Agency to regulate the reuse initiative.Council officials have also confirmed that people who leave items at household recycling centres must consent to them being reused.Groups keen to recycle items which have been left at the local centres will also be required to submit a business case detailing how they will be collected, refurbished and reused, in addition to maintaining a record of all material removed.Also this week, the local authority has confirmed that it plans to expand a pilot mattress recycling scheme at all its household centres including Downpatrick, Ballynahinch and Castlewellan.The pilot was launched in April and to date, , mattresses have been collected at sites across the district.The council says that  per cent of material in mattresses is recyclable and confirmed that the additional cost to ratepayers for the recycling scheme to continue until the end of the financial year is in the region of pound, per annum, based on recycling , mattresses.It has also been confirmed extending the mattress scheme into   needs to be considered as part of the rates estimates process.Downpatrick councillor, Dermot Curran, has welcomed the initiative to allow groups across the district to remove material from household recycling centres to give them new le.He revealed that a number of years ago, the former Down Council looked at an ambitious plan to turn waste into cash by recycling hundreds of tonnes of unwanted household items and sell them to the public. At the time, it was suggested the move could generate an annual income of pound,.ldquoIt was also suggested that such a project could create a number of new jobs, said Cllr Curran. ldquoThis latest initiative is very innovative and I have every confidence that it will be a success, providing a boost for a number of groups and charities which do tremendous work at the heart of their respective communities.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThere are many positives and benefits associated with this scheme and it is something which would make a positive contribution to the district..prettyPhoto

title: Hot Morgan leaves it so late
story: CROSSGAR Golf Club held its last lsquomajorrsquo of the year when Ian Patterson hosted his Presidentrsquos Day at the weekend.The weather was set fair with glorious sunshine as the first groups took to the fairways and it was none other than club captain Leslie Watson who set the early pace, signing for a superb  points.There were to be many challenges along the way with numerous players getting  points, but when usual playing partner Derek Coulter fell just short with  pointsit looked like the day belonged to Watson.Despite the winds picking up in the afternoon, Tony Morgan, in the penultimate group out on the course, came in with a fantastic  points to steal the glory and win his second lsquomajorrsquo in as many years.Some consolation for the Watson family came with David winning his customary gross prize whilst Neil Brown and Neil Hanvey won the front and back nines respectively.It was also a good day for young Andrew Lennon who won the nearest the pin, longest drive and also had the only two of the day.The ladiesrsquo event also had an early pacesetter in the form of Joyce Dodd who posted a great round of  points and she had to sit agonisingly all day and watch challenge after challenge fall short before finally being announced the winner.Catherine Milhench bagged another podium place this year with the runners-up spot on  points and Joan Dickson also added to her silverware of the season with third place on  points.Jane Baker got the nod for the front nine prize with  points whilst Patricia Magee sealed the back nine with a superb  points. Maeve Fay, not for the first time this season, won the battle of the big hitters to win the longest drive.Mr Patterson voiced his delight during his presentation speech at the great turnout of prize winners and congratulated them all.He also paid particular thanks to the ladies for supplying all players with food throughout the day and to the green keepers for the fantastic condition of the course..prettyPhoto

title: Huge response to plans for £12m Portaferry public realm scheme
story: ALMOST  people have responded to public consultation on a planned pound.m public realm scheme in Portaferry.The project is one of two being proposed for the town, following recent confirmation of a pound, investment in upgrading a number of tourist facilities in the village.Ards and North Down Council is spearheading both schemes, with hopes that the public realm initiative could start in  monthsrsquo time.Recently, residents were asked for their input into this particular scheme which focuses on landscape and civil engineering improvements.Specialist consultants have been appointed to design and deliver the scheme in the heart of the town with a specic focus on Market Square, Castle Street, Ferry Street, High Street and Meeting House Street.The aim of the scheme is to create a safe and attractive route for pedestrians through the town as well as one that celebrates and interprets Portaferryrsquos local history and architectural heritage.Planned public realm improvements include widening footpaths, creating better pedestrian connectivity, improving street lighting, resurfacing footpaths, enhanced street furniture, possible traffic flow improvement and new tree and shrub planting.Other improvements include redesigning the Market Square car park and the use of high quality, natural stone in the Market Square and adjacent streets.A pre-application community consultation event was held in Portaferry three weeks ago and it is hoped that a formal application paving the way for work to start will be submitted in October, with the green light for work to start expected as early as next February.Technical design and procurement is is expected to take up to eight months to complete with contractors on site in September next year.Council officials have suggested that construction work could take up to nine months to complete and thatall the pieces in the development jigsaw fall into place, the public realm scheme could conclude in May .Last week,  responses to the planned public realm scheme were handed over to Ards and North Down Council officials by Portaferry resident Colm McCarthy who was joined by Strangford MP Jim Shannon.He thanked Mr McCarthy for gathering the huge number of responses and explained the resident will be meeting with senior council officials to discuss the planned scheme further.ldquoIt is essential that when public money is being spent, consultation with the public is an intricate part of the process, said Mr Shannon.The MP added: ldquoI am hopeful that the council will be lending weight to the concerns and ideas of Colm and the other  people that made representation through him on this planned investment in Portaferry.The planned upgrade of tourist facilities focuses on an area around the Exploris aquarium.Proposals include reopening the caravan park, additional car and coach parking, a new footpath, public toilet block and the resurfacing of the Ropewalk.It is also hoped that a turbine blade from the SeaGen tidal stream generator which was based in The Narrows in the heart of Strangford Lough and donated to Portaferry could feature in the pound, regeneration scheme.Ambitious plans to upgrade tourist facilities in the village were unveiled at a recent meeting of the local councilrsquos Regeneration and Development Committee..prettyPhoto

title: Life Changes group treading the boards
story: MORE than  people recently enjoyed amazing entertainment from The Bright Umbrella Drama Company in the Le Change Changes Lives base in Downpatrick.Over two consecutive nights at the charityrsquos Market Street base, two one hour plays mdash entitled lsquoHope and Alcoholrsquo and lsquoPure Mentalrsquo were performed with powerful, educational, and thought provoking messages about alcoholism, mental health, and suicide intervention.Featuring Trevor Gill, lsquoHope  Alcoholrsquo was a one-man monologue about a manrsquos daily battle with alcoholism, losing everything, his mental illness, and suicide ideation.Trevorrsquos character, Alan, touched the audience with its honest, no holds barred, stripped bare story of his le through losing it all and reclaiming it with some humorous and very entertaining karaoke thrown in to strengthen the message that there is always hope out there and, that with addiction, you are never alone and can come back no matter how far your journey has taken you.There was a strong message that there is always hope and love no matter how bad things seem.ldquoPure Mentalrsquo was a three-man play featuring the cast of The Bright Umbrella Drama Company, taking a lighter take on all aspects of mental health.From John Wayne to Dr Hertz van Rental, the play laid out how to cope with mental health issues using the five steps to wellness approach.These were explained in song, dance and comedy, with the audience learning that there have been so many very famous people with mental health issues.Both evenings were full of fun and sadness, laughter and tears, and a pin could be heard toduring many of the emotional scenes performed by Trevor Gill, Glen McGovern, and Kieran McKernon, assisted by the very able and seamless stage management by Christine Clark.South Down MLA, Colin McGrath, joined the audience for both evenings and conducted interesting question and answer sessions at the end of each.He also expressed his appreciation of the performances by the talented actors and their powerful message with acknowledgement to Ailish and Manus Teague at Le Change Changes Lives and Pop Up Art for how they are addressing the issues of mental health and suicide intervention in the heart of the town..prettyPhoto

title: MP asks for review of opening times at Down Leisure Centre
story: SENIOR Newry, Mourne and Down Council officials have agreed to examine the potential for extending the opening hours of the Down Leisure Centre.The poundm facility in Downpatrick has enjoyed major success since it opened last year with the number of people using the ultra-modern complex exceeding predictions.South Down MP, Chris Hazzard, who asked the local authority to extend the opening hours of the Market Street leisure centre to improve access to its range of facilities, is delighted that the issue is being explored, with a focus on an earlier morning opening.ldquoI welcome the confirmation from council officials that they are going to explore the possibility of extending the centrersquos opening hours and look forward to meeting with senior officials in the weeks ahead to see how this can best be achieved, said Mr Hazzard.ldquoThe local community understands that this canrsquot be simply done at the stroke of a pen that the council must be diligent and needs to accurately assess demand for the facilities and consult with staff regarding any subsequent impact on their terms and conditions and rota patterns etc.Mr Hazzard said he has no doubt that this can all be done successfully in the weeks ahead and that a much more flexible opening times can be achieved to ensure the community has the best possible opportunity to access modern health and fitness facilities at affordable prices..prettyPhoto

title: New history trail opens as 100%2C000th visitor enjoys Montalto Estate
story: CELEBRATIONS were very much the order of the day at the Montalto Estate in Ballynahinch last week.The attraction mdash aimed at reconnecting people with nature through its magnicent surroundings mdash officially opened a new history trail.Last Thursdayrsquos opening coincided with the attractionrsquos first birthday, recent news that the stunning estate had recently welcomed its ,th visitor and a five star visitor attraction grading from Tourism NI.Revealing an ancient settlement site, the location of the famous Battle of Ballynahinch and a stunning viewpoint commanding a vista of the surrounding countryside, the new history trail provides .km of wonderful woodland views.There is also an array of wildle and an opportunity to visit historic sites and to help visitors learn more about the history of Ballynahinch and the surrounding area.Key trail highlights include the Edenavaddy Hill viewpoint, a key interface during the Battle of Ballynahinch, which offers an excellent vantage point to admire the scenic countryside surrounding the estate.The battle took place during the  Irish rebellion between British forces led by Major-General George Nugent and the local United Irishmen led by Henry Munro .At the battle site, visitors are reminded to look out to seethey can spot some soldiers and rebels taking up position near the battle site.The Ancient settlement site surrounded by beautul woodland includes a well-preserved rath, the type of which were common in Ireland during the early Medieval period.Fans of nature and wildle are encouraged to listen out for the soothing calls of wood pigeons, the frequent rasp of the raven and the eerie cry of the buzzard that are common on this walk, along with many ieties of plants and trees.Owned by the Wilson family, the Montalto visitor experience features public access to the estatersquos gardens, historic walks and trails, an exciting tree house and natural play area for children. There is also a welcome area featuring interpretation of the estatersquos history, a stylish -seat cafeacute and a unique retail space.ldquoWe are delighted to open up yet another signicant part of Montalto Estate for visitors to explore and enjoy, said managing director David Wilson.ldquoSteeped in interesting history dating back hundreds of years, we are proud that we can now share more of this with our visitors. While the new history trail is a little more challenging in places, walkers will be rewarded with a snapshot into the past as well as a scenic viewpoint over Ballynahinch town and the surrounding area.Mr Wilson added: ldquoAlong with our existing assets, our new trail simply adds to the unique visitor experience at Montalto. The team very much look forward to welcoming new and ing visitors and we trust that they will have a very memorable experience with us.Down High School vice-principal, historian and author Ken Dawson, said it is important to recognise the signicance of Montalto Estate in local history.He said the launch of the new trail featuring the Battle of Ballynahinch certainly helps to mark this fact.Mr Dawson added: ldquoIt is fantastic that people can now see for themselves where the Battle of Ballynahinch took place.ldquoThis is a must-see experience for those interested in this historical period. The owners have done a wonderful job opening the space up to visitors and I would encourage everyone to come and see it for themselves.The estatersquos opening hours are Wednesday to Sunday between am and pm, with access to the site, including car park, welcome area, cafeacute and shop free. Gardens, trails and walks are ticketed with prices starting from pound.and children aged five to , pound. Discounted rates are available when you book in advance online, while children under five are admitted free..prettyPhoto

title: Railway plans £750k expansion
story: A MAJOR expansion plan by the Downpatrick and Co Down Railway could be set to get back on track.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council Committee is to look at vesting private land to allow the heritage railway to press ahead with a pound, extension to Ballydugan.The decision was taken at last weekrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee, but theproposal has to be formally ratied by the full council when it meets next month.Members of the council committee have agreed to instruct their legal team to begin the vesting process, subject to a suitable valuation being agreed and all necessary formalities being completed.Heritage railway chairman Robert Gardiner said he was delighted with the local authorityrsquos continued support, explaining that the process to acquire the land was started by the former Down Council in .ldquoWe are pleased that the new council is keen to take our expansion plan forward, he said. ldquoWhile there was a suggestion that part of the derelict and disused line would have been used as a so-called greenway, developing it as a heritage railway line now seems to be the preferred option.ldquoThe railway had a tremendously successful summer and we hope that we can secure the land we require to allow the extension to proceed. We appreciate that while this may only be the start of the process, we would call on the landowners to talk to us and the local council.Mr Gardiner added: ldquoOur door is open and we are happy to chat. We very much view ourselves as good neighbours. We hope that moving forward agreement can be reached.Since , work has progressed and a number of studies completed in an effort to advance the planned railway extension, including the completion of a revised business case, along a disused section of line.Council officials argue that the planned extension would help the local authority meet of one its key objectives in transforming the district into one of Irelandrsquos premier tourist destinations and help attract and promote economic investment, enhancing the visitor experience.In addition, council officials are confident that extending the heritage railway line would assist with the regeneration of a rural area.The local authority said attempts to negotiate a settlement with three landowners at the Ballydugan end of the railway line had not been successful.As a result, the local authorityrsquos lawyers are to be asked to proceed with a vesting application to allow heritage railway officials to progress discussions with prospective project funders.Downpatrick councillors Cadogan Enright and Dermot Curran have welcomed the proposal to vest the land.Cllr Enright mdash who formally proposed that the vesting process should commence mdash said the former Down Council earmarked finance to acquire the land to pave the way for the railwayrsquos extension.He said given the inability to persuade current owners of unused track bed toit to public ownership ldquovesting has become necessary.Cllr Enright added: ldquoWe have been trying to get this done voluntarily for the past  years and more and I am delighted that the Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee is backing the proposal to proceed with vesting.Cllr Curran said the local railway had been a ldquomajor success since it opened and had managed to secured hundreds of thousands of pounds in funding from a iety of sources to provide an attraction which is second to none.ldquoThe railway is one of the most popular attractions of its kind in Northern Ireland and has had ambitious expansion plans on the table for some time, he continued.ldquoThe local authority has put tourism at the top of its agenda and extending the railway, I believe, would be a major boost for the area. An extended railway would also be able to ferry punters to and from Downpatrick racecourse on race days.Cllr Curran said he hopes that the vesting process can be completed smoothly and relatively quickly with agreement between all the parties to allow the railwayrsquos extension plan to proceed..prettyPhoto

title: Safety upgrade work begins at roundabout
story: WORK has started on a major safety upgrade at one of the districtrsquos most busiest roads.Contractors moved on site at the Dundrum Rod roundabout in Newcastle on Monday to provide new puffin crossing points which will require traffic to come to a complete stop to allow people to cross the road.The new crossings are being provided at the Dundrum and Castlewellan road sides of the roundabout and will replace existing zebra crossings. The work is scheduled to last five weeks.Major concerns voiced by residents and local politicians about pedestrian safety at this part of the resort mdash where there have been countless near misses particularly at the Dundrum Road side of the roundabout mdash prompted roads officials to act. Some pedestrians have also been struck by vehicles.The provision of new puffin crossings will result in traffic lights being provided either side of the roundabout, with the move welcomed by Mournes councillor, Willie Clarke.He described the provision of the new crossings as a ldquolong overdue priority for pedestrian safety in Newcastle explaining that they will help reduce pedestrian collisions and near misses at a particularly busy part of the resort.ldquoAlong with other elected representatives, community and residentsrsquo groups, the local Policing and Community Safety Partnership and the public I have campaigned for the replacement of the zebra crossing with a controlled lights crossing, said Cllr Clarke.ldquoI have campaigned for this road safety measure for over a decade and am delighted work has started this week. I would also urge motorists to be patient and allow more time for their journeys over the next five weeks as the work progresses.Describing the new road safety measure as a lsquolong overdue priority, Cllr Clarke said the new crossings will be warmly welcomed.He said that also as part of the scheme, a new footpath will be created at the Castlewellan Road side of the roundabout linking the new puffin crossing at the Dundrum Road side.Cllr Clarke added: ldquoThe ongoing work will provide safe, controlled crossing facilities and will assist with reducing personal injury collisions recorded at the roundabout.News of work starting on the new crossings comes weeks after roads officials scrapped another proposal to address road safety and congestion issues at the roundabout.The Department of Infrastructure was planning to create a new dedicated filter lane at the Dundrum Road side of the roundabout, designed to enable drivers entering the resort from this direction, wishing to access the Castlewellan Road, to do so without causing major tailbacks.The scheme mdash which had not been fully costed mdash would have left two existing lanes for the exclusive use of traffic heading into the centre of Newcastle.Roads engineers were confident that the proposal would have signicantly reduced congestion, but it was recently confirmed at a special meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council that the plug had been pulled on the scheme.Local politicians were told that the project was not viable given the number of underground utilities at this part of the resort. However, roads officials confirmed that they are in the process of drawing up an alternative scheme, the detail of which they hope to unveil shortly..prettyPhoto

title: Smyth first home at Finnebrogue Woods
story: OVER  athletes took part in inaugural M B McGrady  Co Chartered Accountants Beer and Bubbles charity run at Finnebrogue Woods last Thursday night.Sunny weather made for perfect running conditions for the race that took place in Finnebrogue Woods, on the outskirts of Downpatrick.Prizes were awarded to fastest male, David Smyth and fastest female, Carissa McLister, who completed her first ever km race. Fteen year-old Fergus McGrady was the second male across the line, and Gillian Grant, a chartered accountant at M B McGrady  Co, was the female runner-up.Conaill McGrady, director of M B McGrady  Co Chartered Accountants, was delighted with how everything went on the night.ldquoWe are thrilled with the success of our first ever charity km, thousands have been raised through the generosity of those taking part, which will be donated to our charity partner Air Ambulance NI, he said.ldquoA special thank you to local businesses who came onboard as lsquokmrsquo sponsors, Denvirrsquos Hotel, RNN Communications, Scullion and Green Solicitors, McGrady Financial and Hugh J OrsquoBoyle, as well as local event management company,  Extreme.ldquoA special mention of thanks to Ed and Rachael Lindsay of Finnebrogue Woods for enabling the run to take place in the stunning back of the woodland trails, he added.ldquoAnd finally, a big thank you goes to all those who put on their running shoes and contributed to making the event such a success, raising vital funds for our chosen charity.The event was open to competitors of all ages and experiences and took runners through the idyllic woodland venue where they finished up close to the lakeside.Taking in the breathtaking views, runners soaked up the atmosphere while enjoying a glass of local beer or prosecco.With three offices in Northern Ireland, M B McGrady  Co Chartered Accountants are located in Downpatrick, Belfast and Newtownards..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. lsquoHost a School Chefrsquo project.Ms Morgan, who is head cook at St Cyres school, was selected by the Vale council to take part in the scheme.Colleagues had praised her outstanding work ethic, talent and team spirit, and felt she would thrive in the experience.Ms Morgan said: ldquoI thoroughly enjoyed the experience at the James Sommerin restaurant.ldquoI learnt a lot about seasonal produce and thinking outside the box when it comes to meals.ldquoSeeing the team at work reinforced in my mind the great work wersquore doing at St Cyres.ldquoWersquore a strong and efficient team, and I feel I am a good manager.ldquoIt made me appreciate the job Irsquom doing now, and I realise I wouldnrsquot change it for the world.Ms Morgan was welcomed by Mr Sommerin and his daughter Georgia to help prepare food for service in the multi award-winning restaurant, on Penarth Esplanade.She spent a day on-site, gaining knowledge on flavour combinations, and making the most of what the seasons have to offer, as well as having the opportunity to observe and ask questions.Ms Morgan hopes to transfer these new-found skills to the school environment, catering for balanced and nutritious meals for  to -year olds.Initially part of LACArsquos National School Meals Week events, the Host a School Chef project became so popular with school caterers and restaurateurs that it is now promoted as a stand-alone, year-round event.The project allows school chefs the opportunity to gain experience in some of the countryrsquos most exclusive restaurant kitchens.Prior restaurants hosting school chefs title: aberthaw power station set close
story: ABERTHAW Power Station at sunset.." Aberthaw Power Station set to close in Aberthaw Power Station." Aberthaw Power Station set to close in Aberthaw Power Station." Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentABERTHAW, the last coal fired power station in Wales, is set to close in .RWE is proposing to close the .-megawatt Aberthaw B Power Station in the Vale of Glamorgan on March .The plant was due to stay open until . In , it was found to have produced illegal amounts of pollution.It currently employs  staff.CEO of RWE Generation, Roger Miesen said: ldquoMarket conditions made this decision necessary."Director of Friends of the Earth Cymru, Haf Elgar welcomed the news.ldquoThe writingrsquos on the wall for the coal industry ndash we cannot keep burning fossil fuels in a climate emergency and we must stop now. she said. ldquoItrsquos welcome news that Walesrsquo last coal fired power station is set to close."Combined with the Welsh Governmentrsquos announcement at the end of last year that there should be no new coal mining in Wales, so finally we will be able to say that coal is history.ldquoWe must now re-energise our efforts to cut emissions to net zero, and secure solutions to climate change that support communities throughout Wales, creating green jobs, and a healthy sustainable future for us all without damaging our climate and wildle.Vale AM Jane Hutt said: ldquoI have supported the loyal and skilled workforce at Aberthaw over the past  years and want their loyalty recognised by RWE given the assurances we have had of a longer le for the plant.ldquoI am speaking to RWE management and the unions about the situation drawing on Welsh Government support for those losing their jobs.ldquoThe Welsh Government will make available its normal package of support for iniduals impacted by this news ndash through our Employability Programme, ReAct funding as well as facilitating Careers Wales and DWP advice.ldquoThese are loyal, dedicated staff who, with their families, are part of the Vale of Glamorgan community I serve.Vale-based South Wales Central AM Andrew RT Davies added: ldquoThe closure of Aberthaw Power Station will mark the end of an era, with the site having been a power station for generations.ldquoObviously, with the increasing reliance on renewables, this news was expected, and the site has been on notice for some time.ldquoBut it is vital proper support and arrangements are now put in place for the staff working on the site, so that we can find them other roles.ldquoAlso, many residents have contacted me over recent months expressing concerns over what may happen to the site when the plant closes.ldquoIt is therefore crucial that proper safeguards are put in place for when decommissioning occurs. article_url   content_id   site_id title: penarth hold prehistoric themed vegan fair paget rooms
story: Absolutely Fabulous Vegan Fairs, running from pm to pm, will charge adults pound, with children under  going free.Meat-eaters, veggies and vegans will love the event.Many meat-eatersagain and again, making the transition to veganism inspiring the Prehistoric theme.This year organiser Sue Thomas is thrilled to announce vegan GP Dr Sue Kenneally will give a talk on stage at pm entitled lsquoTake the lsquodiersquo out of dietrsquo.The talk, taking roughly  to  minutes, will see the speaker, nutritionist, GP and writer discuss her turn to a plant-based diet.Leaflets from plant-based health professionals will be given out and visitors are encouraged to talk with Dr Keneally before the event.Sue Thomas said: ldquoDr Keneally is so passionate and I can tell such a natural person. She is the type of person you feel you have known all your le.ldquoI met her for lunch yesterday at the opening of the fabulous Greens Vegan in Cardf for lunch. She is one of the most magical, unassuming people I have ever met, beautul inside and out.ldquoSue is a person I would put all my faith in to discuss a medical condition, and I would not hesitate to recommend visiting her privately about plant-based lestyle medicine.ldquoDiscuss her appointments available at Cyncoed Cardf Consulting Rooms.Amazing vegan and vegetarian food can be found across the event.Hot food is served upstairs, with Caribbean, Indian and Kenyan dishes served by Caerphillyrsquos The Vegan Box Limited. Tables and chairs will be set out for lunch from pm. Takeaways are also available.Downstairs will see stalls including:l A double stall from Windsor Fruit Stores, Penarth, selling organic fruit and veg and vegan goodiesl Crepe Escape of Penarth selling refreshments and wonderful slices of vegan cakesl Mr Nice Piel Alicersquos Vegan Kitchenl Cakes from the fabulous Naked Veganl Gluten-free chocolates from Irene DuncanAnd we are thrilled to have the soft-served, coconut-based ice cream from Greens Vegan. Greens Vegan is the new, totally vegan company recently opened at , Windsor Place, Cardf.Tropic will sell cruelty-free makeup and skincare products.Norwex Household Products and Utility Warehouse will have stalls.Children will love the biodegradable glitter facepainting and Jessica Abbot will also sell beautul cruelty-free makeup, suitable for vegans.In the Prehistoric Fun corner in the foyer, there will be dinosaurs colouring and more. Nicola Hale of Penarth-based Dunwich Pottery will help children and adults get into pottery painting, with dinosaurs and ious other prehistoric characters to paint.Hillside Animal Sanctuary and Dean Farm Trust will be operating their usual free stalls, and the event will have a cat rescue stall.If it isnrsquot too hot out, organiser Sue Thomas will dress as a crocodile to meet and greet attendees, and encourages visitors to dress up too.Ms Thomas said: ldquoThis will be a wonderful event. title: new rural vale film festival set premiere september
story: The Vale councilrsquos rural regeneration initiative has set up Hidden Here, which celebrates the concentration of creative talent throughout the Vale.It aims to animate some of the Valersquos venues like Cosmeston Medieval Village, St Donats Castle and DRESD Studios in St Athan with a iety of immersive events.Festival goers can take part in discussions and masterclasses on green screen, make up, prosthetics, set and prop work, animation and puppeteering workshops and a question and answer session with industry experts.There will be an extensive programme of film screenings, including classics like Top Gun, The Great Escape and Jurassic Park, along with newer titles like Early Man, Rocketman and Kingsman: The Secret Service.As part of the event, aspiring film-makers will have the opportunity to enter a short film competition, producing a one minute short.The competition is supported and will be judged by The University South Wales Film and Television School.DRESD Studios will also be hosting the Guinness World Record attempt for the largest ever film quiz as part of the festival finale on October .A total of  competitors will be grouped in teams of  and immersed into props and sets from popular films and TV shows.The project has received funding through the Vale council and the Wales Rural Development Programme, which is in turn funded by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the Welsh Government.Cabinet member for art, leisure and culture, Cllr Kathryn McCaffer said: ldquoThere is an abundance of culture and talent in the Vale, and the council is committed to supporting initiatives that help cultivate that talent.ldquoWe as Vale residents are privileged to have had this project brought to our doorsteps, with plenty of exciting and erse events taking place over the two weeks. Without a doubt, there will be something for everyone.Madeleine Sims, rural regeneration officer and curator of the festival said: ldquoWe are supporting some really unique projects across the festival, many of which are free for the public.ldquoSome include making a short documentary on the Big Issue sellers in the Vale, supporting an oral history project and hosting a Second World War event at the Aerospace Park in St Athan."To mark the th anniversary of Apocalypse Now, wersquoll host a special screening in an air hangar, surrounded by aircraft from the era.ldquoThe response from the rural community has been astonishing, and wersquore very excited to get underway.The short film competition is now open for entries on www.valefilmfest and the full film festival program and tickets will be available from August . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: Former marine Max Glover has raised pound for charity" Ex-marine takes on marathon for charity - while towing a carMr Glover was inspired to raise by his friend Julie Parker, who recently had a dltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtouble lung transplanltspan classtruncate-full-screengttlt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" Ex-marine takes on marathon for charity - while towing a carMr Glover attached himself to a . tonne BMW d with a harness and walked .ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgt mileslt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA BODYBUILDER has taken on the extraordinary fundraising challenge of walking a marathon - while towing a car.On August , bodybuilder and ex-marine Max Glover attached himself to a . tonne BMW d with a harness, and walked . miles within  hours, raising over pound for Royal Brompton and Harefield Hospitals Charity.Mr Glover, born in Penarth and now living in Cardf, travelled to Bruntinghthorpe Proving Ground in Leicestershire ndash who allowed him to use the track for  hours.Mr Glover was inspired to raise by his friend Julie Parker, who recently had a lung transplant at Harefield Hospital. Ms Parker and Mr Glover met several years ago when he trained her at their local gym. They then ended up unexpectedly working together later in le when Mr Glover changed jobs.Mr Glover said: ldquoIt was very tough for Julie before the transplant as she suffered with a genetic lung disease and her lungs slowly stopped working over a few years."It got to the point where she required an oxygen tank to be strapped to her back so that she could breathe. She never gave up and still worked and tried to do as much as she could and always kept a smile on her face.Ms Parker has a rare condition called Alpha--antitrypsin deficiency which means she lacks a protective enzyme inhibitor which makes her more vulnerable to smoke, dust and other toxic materials and increases the risk of lung disease. Because of the deficiency, Ms Parker was required to have a double lung transplant. Shortly after the transplant Ms Parker went to lunch with Mr Glover and he was amazed at how well she looked.He said: ldquoBecause I was seeing her every day, I knew her health was declining as a result of the lung disease. But I donrsquot think I was so aware of the extent until I saw her after the operation, and how healthy she looked.This isnrsquot the first challenge Mr Glover has taken on.In the past he has carried lbs up and down the highest mountain in Southern Britain, completed car dead lts and successfully performed  pull ups.The pair now plan to walk Pen-Y-Fan, the highest mountain in South Wales, together to raise money in the future once Ms Parker is well enough.Mr Glover set out to raise pound, and has now raised pound.Officially, Mr Glover had only  days to train for this challenge, enlisting friends to help him by sitting in the car and steering as he tows.ldquoI was getting up at :am to run around car parks towing the car with a harness before work," he said. "I love setting myself challenges but donrsquot tend to do what everyone  does. So I will look for something a bit far out or invent my own and usually try and document them on video.All the proceeds from the day will go towards the charityrsquos Harefield Transplant Appeal, to raise funds for organ care systems to allow more patients to receive le-saving transplants.If yoursquod like to support Mr Glover in his marathon challenge his Justgiving page is: https:www.justgiving fundraising muscleworld article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
